Legal_Issue: Whether the RAD erred in accepting the RPD's finding that the applicant could likely return to India
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed inability to return to India based on NORI stamp; no evidence presented regarding visa denials
Decision_Outcome: RAD did not err; refugee claim dismissed
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of RAD's dismissal of appeal
Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of persecution upon return to country of origin
Legal_Standard: Reasonableness standard for RAD decisions unless unconsidered evidence is involved
Assessment_Factor: Ability to return to country of former habitual residence
Evidence_Used: NORI stamp status, lack of evidence on visa denial
Legal_Provision_Cited: IRPA provisions on refugee protection and return to country of origin
Application_Basis: Perceived ability to return to India without risk
Evidence_Assessed: Absence of evidence showing visa denial or entry refusal by India
Relief_Sought: Overturning of RAD decision and acceptance of refugee claim
Governing_Rule: If individual cannot return due to risk of persecution, protection may be warranted under IRPA
Evidentiary_Deficiency: No evidence provided to RPD about actual or likely visa denial by India
Cause_Description: Applicant's refugee claim denied due to perceived ability to return to India
Evidence_Handling: RAD found insufficient evidence to establish inability to return
Evidence_Issues: Lack of supporting evidence on visa requirements and entry denial
Legal_Provision: IRPA sections related to refugee determination and eligibility
Evidence_Assessment: RAD assessed absence of evidence as failure to meet burden of proof
Decision_Rationale: Applicant failed to prove inability to return to India; no error in RPD or RAD findings
Decision_Making_Body: Refugee Protection Division (RPD), Refugee Appeal Division (RAD)
Evidentiary_Issues: Failure to provide evidence on visa denial despite NORI stamp
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard in reviewing RAD decisions
